summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report of a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) guard from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding his activities and observations on August 9, 2019, the day Jeffrey Epstein died. The guard describes his shift, Epstein's movements, a phone call Epstein made, and inconsistencies in his account of rounds and paperwork procedures.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who died on August 9, 2019. The interview focuses on the guard's observations of Epstein's activities and condition on that day.

persons.name: Noel
persons.context: A fellow BOP guard present in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on August 9, 2019. The interviewee states Noel filled out the 30-minute round paperwork.

persons.name: Special Agent
persons.context: One of the interviewing agents from the FBI, along with an OIG agent and AUSAs.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: Present during the interview of the BOP guard, representing the Southern District of New York.

connections.description: Noel was a guard responsible for monitoring Epstein in the Special Housing Unit on the day of his death.
The FBI agent is investigating the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein's Activities and Death in Custody
events.description: The day Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in his cell at the MCC. The interview details his activities that day, including being with lawyers, making a phone call, and his condition before the guard's shift ended.

events.title: FBI Interview of BOP Guard
events.description: FBI, OIG, and AUSAs interview a BOP guard regarding his shift and observations on August 9, 2019, the day Epstein died.

keyFacts: A BOP guard was interviewed about his activities on August 9, 2019, which he referred to as 'EPSTEIN day'.
The guard stated Epstein was with his lawyers for most of the day and that he assisted Epstein in making a phone call from the G tier shower around 8 pm.
The guard reported that another inmate's suicide threat diverted guards' attention from Epstein.
The guard admitted to inconsistencies in his account of conducting rounds and signing paperwork, suggesting he may have signed off on rounds not conducted due to pressure.
The guard stated he last saw Epstein around 9:30 pm, asked if he was 'good,' and received a thumbs up, and that Epstein seemed normal.
